bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Thomas, Lord Fairfax, May 21, 1730

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Thomas, Lord Fairfax, proprietor of the Northern Neck, May 21, 1730, concerning a lease Fairfax has given Bristol merchants, noting that he had encouraged them but told them it would be some time before Fairfax would receive any profits from their venture. He turns to the attempt he and his family are mking to exploit signs of copper, but notes their discouragement. He understands that Fairfax will consult with Michajah Perry about defending the boundaries of the proprietary, and a new lease of it for Carter. The reports of iron mining are not to be relied upon because the cost of transporting the ore is very high. He turns to attacks in the colony upon the proprietary, noting that there may be action when the Assembly meets soon since there have already been attempts to change the boundaries.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Thomas, Lord Fairfax, May 21, 1730

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
May 21, 1730
The Rt.. Honorable
the Lord Fairfax—

div1.p:
The honour you did me in a letter of the 9th of Novr
last did not reach my hands 'till the 9th of March. in it you are
pleas'd to acquaint me with the Leas you had transacted with some
Bristol Merchts and to desire me to permit them to work unmolested from
whence I conjecture they had given yr Lordship information of some
desturbance I had threatned them with if they have said any thing of
this nature to your Lordship 'tis a very wrong charge I was so far
from discouraging that I encourag'd them all I could in their design. One
of their partners here Offer'd to compound with me for your Lordship['s]
share to whom I answer'd their Adventures would be carry'd on to so
little purpose in my time that I should not concern myself about it any
further than to wish them a great deal of success and when I saw your
Lordships leas which was shew'd me by Colo Tayloe one of their part=
ners I told him I was glad that your Lordship had made such a
favourable step to their design but I believe twill be a great While before
any benefit by this leas will arise to your Lordship the Undertakers
have made very little progress yet and have not sent in [in] this Shipp
[i]ng any people skilld in the Affair to carry on their business and as
I am told are under a great deal of discouragements and have sent for
home their chief Workman whom they sent in on purpose for this design
to give them an Accot of his discoverys which have turn'd to very little
yet.

In my letter to your Lordship of the 24th of June
last amongst many other things I gave you an Account of this place
where the Bristol men are upon and also of another that had some
shews of Copper this other place lyes high up Potomack and far from
water some others of my family with myself have been at considerable
charge already to find out what this place will yeild but to little purpose
hitherto in our first searches we met with some veins of ore amounting to
some few tonnes which we are now Sending, for
——
England
to make a tryal of what Value they are but as we went deeper the
veins grew less and instead of increasing our hopes we are very doubt=
full we may never find out any Considerable body of ore Worth our
While however we intend to push on our Tryals a Little further what
I tell this Story to your Lordship for is that we are in hopes as your
Ldship hath gone into a leas with the Bristol Men to give encourag=
ement to these designs so you will Pleas to come into the same measures
with us in favour of our design if ever We Can bring it to Anything

In the latter part of your Lordships letter you Acquaint
me that When Mr. Perry return'd to London you should pursue such
Measures in relation to your boundaries as Should Appear most prope[r]
Mr Perry writes to me to the same purpose and as to the renewing of my
leas you had promis'd to do it after his return from the Bath from whence
I have reason to Conclude these matters are effected before this time

Your Lordship tells me you expected some proposals abo[u]t
the Iron Works I cannot see how any Advantage can be made to
yr. Lordship from them Works the ore lyes near the Surface of the earth
they buy it for little or nothing from the Owners of the Land I have been
Several times at the place my self they rais it with very little trouble
or Charge their great chuarge is in Carting it down about 9 miles to
a landing and from thence Water bearing it about 40 more to their
furnace now what advantage it will be to yr Lordship or anybody
under you to demand apart [sic] of this ore where 'tis dugg I cant con=
jecture

I am now to acquaint your Ldship of a fresh Attack
is lately made against yr Grant who have been the Springs of it
I shall not take upon me to Say but there are now grievances sent
from the inhabitants of most of the Countys within your grant com
plaining of the hardships they are under by it and desiring that the
King may be addresst either to purchase or reassume the Grant that
they may be under the same circumstances that the rest of the Country
are
What these complaints may be Workt up to in our Assembly which sits
down to day I cant pretend to tell I have already told yr Lordship what
potent enemies our revenue gentlemen were against the boundaries
&ca. and there's no Doubt to be made but their utmost strength will be
imploy'd in Carrying this Complaint to the highest Pitch their
fingers itch to have this grant added to their places and I have rea=
son to think that these disturbances have much encourag'd the inha
bitants to be very backward in paying their rents altho I am forc'd
to take them in tobo and that not to be sold now for 3 S per hundr'd
for I never had so few of the rents receiv'd at this time of year before
Since I have been in the business

For my own part in my justification I can say
I have made no Alteration in anything relating to the Execution
of the Grant nor is anything done but What is Very justifyable undr
it I observe the same measures in all my demands as I have done
ever since I was concern'd and as the rist of the agents before me did

I remember about the year 1695. (as I think) such
a [hole in leaf] Struggle was made by greivances to an Assembly [ag=]
ainst the grant and the then house of Burgesses joyn'd in a[n]
Address to the king, to purchase or reassume, it was carry'd to the
Council where it was Stopt and went no further Sir Edmund Andros
was then our governour. I have thought it necessary to lay these things
before yr. Lordship that your Lordship may be 'fore Apprized and enter
upon such measures yr Ldship may think most proper for your secu=
rity to Extricate yourself and those that are imploy'd under you here out
of the sd. difficulties I am
div1.closer:
My Lord Yr Lordships
Most Obt & most humble Servant
ROBERT CARTER

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Additional Manuscripts, 30316, British Library, London, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia. This is the recipient's copy signed by Carter (as is indicated by the use of bold italics). The address leaf reads: The Rt Honble | Thomas Lord Fairfax | Baron of Cameron | at | Leeds Castle | under Alderman Perrys | Cover.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence to persons abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] John Tayloe (1687-1747) of Mt. Airy, Richmond County, who served as justice, burgess, colonel of militia, and as a member of the Council after 1732. (Ryland. Richmond County Virginia. . . . pp. 115-16.)
